The general area in which I live in can be described as your typical cookie cutter suburbia. For my neighborhood in particular, the presence of a homeowner's association is very apparent. Upon entering, you'll see nothing but well-maintained single family homes, which we can thank the homeowner's association for. The front yards are all very similar. There's a small patch of landscaped grass, some decorative pebbles, and rather short driveways. Every so often you'll see small trees as well. Everyone has a two car garage. As you continue to drive along throughout the neighborhood you'll see newly paved concrete. Despite many different families living here, the roads are in excellent condition. You won't find any potholes or anything like that here. Most of the houses are single story, but sometimes you'll see two stories as well. We don't have a typical mailbox set-up that you would expect for single family homes. There are no individual mailboxes in front of each house. Instead, it's more like apartments where there are a large grouping of mailboxes at the end of the street. Everyone uses a key to gain access their specific mailbox. And there's two larger lockers for packages. Again, you can thank the HOA and their obsession with uniformity for this. The location of my house is on the extreme edge of the nearby city, so my neighborhood can be described as part rural, part suburbs. As a result, we have a lot of land for, well, everything. There's multiple community pools to which anyone living here can access. It's well maintained and gated. And then there are various walking trails where you can walk your dog, or just go for an evening stroll by yourself. You don't have to visit a park to get your exercise in. The neighborhood is large enough that you can simply run around it and get more than enough exercise. Most of the community is made up of retired people. It's a very safe area, and everyone looks out for one another. Mixed in with that, we have a small amount of middle aged and young professionals too. In regards to the city, it's surprisingly large - at least by population - but also has a small time town feel. We have the vast majority of amenities that you come to expect and rely on. For example, we have a exactly one mall. It's not huge, but it gets the job done. For me, it takes around 15 minutes of driving to get anywhere significant, but once I do that, I am greeted with many different stores to choose from. We have everything from high end grocery stores where you can get organic food, to bargain outlets that only stock a small selection of items and has bare minimum staff to keep costs down. All in all, my neighborhood is safe, well-maintained, and pretty typical. We have a lot of nice things, like pools and walking trails. And although we aren't right next door to any sort of shopping, you can just hop in a car and go to any major chain that you'd like.
I live in a small Midwestern town that is just outside the suburban areas of a major city. My immediate neighborhood, on the east side of the town, could be described as the most economically disadvantaged area of the town. Property values are low, with most houses being rented to or owned by low-income individuals. However, it is not unattractive or unpleasant. My neighbors are generally friendly people who will smile and say hello when I walk down the street. Crime rates, while slightly higher than other parts of town, are still generally low. There have been a few violent crimes in the past ten years within a few blocks of my home, including a few shootings and at least one homicide. Our next door neighbors lost their son in a shooting outside an area bar last year. Fortunately, our family has not been directly affected by crime other than having an occasional item disappear from our porch if we forget to bring it inside. In general, the town in which I live has been profoundly affected by the “opioid epidemic” that has affected many parts of the United States. Many lives have been lost due to fentanyl overdoses. Fortunately, there are many resources in my town to combat this epidemic, including several addiction rehabilitation centers and Narcan training sessions for families and friends of those affected by addiction. Despite these challenges, this town has many positive attributes. My son’s elementary school has excellent staff, from the principal to the teachers and support staff. Despite having special needs, he has not faced any bullying thus far due to the incredibly positive atmosphere of the school, and he loves it there. We have an active PTO that plans multiple events throughout the year to promote family involvement and educational progress. Because over 20% of our town’s population lives below the poverty level, the elementary school provides free breakfast and lunch to all students, so that no child ever has to go hungry. No child or family is treated as “less than” due to an inability to pay, and costs for school fees, supplies, and field trips are very reasonable. The City Council and staff have made many improvements to the appearance of our town, including repaving roads, landscaping, and refurbishing city parks. Unfortunately, most of these improvements have taken place in the center of town and on the west side, where all of the shopping areas are located and most of the traffic passes through. The east side where I live tends to be neglected, which is a point of contention for those in my neighborhood. Overall, I do enjoy living in this town. People are generally friendly, the schools are great, there are enough shopping options (both small businesses and larger retail stores) to meet my family’s needs, and our home may not be worth much, but it is comfortable and adequate. Our family has lived here for over 16 years, and we cannot imagine living anywhere else.
My neighborhood is full of culture. It's set upon a hill, surrounded by buildings with historical meaning. I live in a 7 story apartment building right across from the old live Theater, and a block down The Hill, is this cool little arcade bar that different types of people flock to on warm summer nights. Often times, especially on the weekends in June and July, you will see a line of people waiting to get in. A few blocks up is the nearest city park. It's pretty big considering the part of town it sits in. Encircling the park is concrete, with tall stairs poured into the wall. During the frigid winter months, homeless people set their tents up in neat little rows along the sidewalk and along the wide steps. It doesn't snow much, but it rains, and the torrential down pour in the mid-winter months often tends to make it difficult to keep warm. Setting their tents up close together, in the center of town rather than out in the jungle, keeps them much warmer. They're also within reasonable walking and transit distance to the only family center for miles, where they can bathe and shower. What I love about my city though, isn't the beauty of the historic nature- the tall proud buildings, the architecture that is spattered through-out the varying levels of the hills that roll down towards the ocean. What I love about my neighborhood is the culture of the people themselves. You see, Hilltop once was the most notorious neighborhood on the West Coast for gang violence. You still hear stories, even three decades later, about the federal government officials and the DEA sweeping through like a broom, trying to clean the streets. The people, they don't forget. Stories are still passed from generation to generation, on through to transplants like me, of those days. The people work hard, even though it's still considered one of the rougher 'hoods' in the entire city, to keep it cleaned up. They still care about what goes on in their city, on their block. They say that if you're white, you shouldn't walk around the Hill after dark. Truly, I believe that this warning is reminiscent of the old days, and it is tinged with the sour taste of social conditioning. Perhaps it is that I am just dark enough to pass for a not entirely "white-girl," or maybe Hilltop recognizes me as one of their own, someone who is just as painfully aware of the reminders that constantly plague our nation. Reminders that racism, cultural conditioning, and assumptions are made out of ignorance and fear, even in a city that is supposed to be a cultural melting pot Utopia. I know one thing: no matter how far I roam, the Hilltop is home. I feel alive walking those streets at night, meeting people who have more quickly and rarely nefariously offered me a jacket than to rob me. It's a place where laundromat owners have stayed open just a few minutes later so I could charge my phone when I had no where to escape from the rain. It's a place where I have sat, believe myself to be invisible, huddled against concrete store fronts on the most grey dreary of nights, only to have someone stop and look me in the eye, hand me a $5, and tell me I'm beautiful and valuable.
I live in Rural America, specifically small town Michigan. Where you go from farmland to small tourist cities. There is no big city malls, no Wal-mart, Target, or even an Applebee’s. Anywhere you need to go, you have to drive to get to. Despite that I live in one of the most beautiful places in the world surrounded by water. My “city” is surrounded by water. Beautiful Lake Michigan to one side, and Lake Charlevoix on the other. Everywhere you go you can find a beach to dip your toes in. My neighborhood, reflects the idea of small town. Houses are not stacked upon one another. They aren’t cookie cutter houses that are built the same. They are older homes, some of them being updated and remodeled some of them being older. Most homes have basements. Full Basements that you can see from the road. Many houses in the neighborhood have older aluminum siding. We have houses every color you can imagine in the blocks that surround my house. Most of the houses have yards. Yards with trampolines, and playsets. Some people have gardens, and fences for their animals. The houses resemble Middle America. Hard working people who work to make a living and are either raising families or have raised families. On any given day you will see kids running up and down the streets. You will also see people walking dogs, biking and rollerblading. Neighbors know neighbors and you can recognize who fits in and who doesn’t belong. You will see someone grilling outside and wave, or even someone that is walking their dog from a few blocks down and smile pleasantly. The lawns are kept in decent condition. Nobody has leaves piled up from fall time. Green grass is kept mowed and under control. If people have plants and bushes in their yards they are kept trimmed down. It isn’t a beautiful neighborhood that you drive into and think wow look at the nice homes, but one you drive into and think you can tell this would be a good place to raise a family. It’s quiet, peaceful and, and safe. While only average looking, it is exceptional for the fact that it represents what people want in the world, which is a safe place to land at the end of the day. Within walking distance there is the county sheriff’s department and jail. The Health department is just next to that. The city recycling center sits just down the road, and neighbors and residents from around the city utilize the services they provide. We have baseball and softball fields nearby where you can hear the announcers keeping score and calling the names of players. Our small town airport is next to that. You can be playing outside, or even inside and hear the rumbles of small engine planes taking off and landing. You can walk to get ice cream from the local ice cream place, and if you are really into it you can make it downtown from our neighborhood of homes. My kids can ride their bikes to the park which is only 8 blocks or so away. It is a really great place to live.
transformed_texts: Growing up in a bustling metropolis, I've come to appreciate the rich diversity that permeates my neighborhood. The layout of the area is quite unique, with residential areas scattered seemingly at random amidst commercial zones, which are home to a wide array of businesses. Office buildings, stores, restaurants, and entertainment venues all coexist in a vibrant mix. With an abundance of new eateries and shopping spots to explore, it's easy to get caught up in the excitement. However, this diversity is not limited to large, well-known brands; small boutiques are increasingly popular and can be found not only in malls but also lining the streets, often just a short walk away from quiet neighborhoods that would otherwise be serene. Nearby parks are also a hotspot for families with young children, offering a peaceful escape from the hustle and bustle. My neighborhood itself boasts a remarkable level of diversity, with a prominent LGBTQ+ community, an Orthodox Jewish community, and a collection of refugees and immigrants from the former Soviet Union all residing in the same area. As one ventures further into the city, more individuals from various racial and ethnic backgrounds can be found, often residing in their own distinct communities. Neighborhoods like Korea town, China town, and Little Armenia are just a short drive away, yet the sheer size of the city makes driving a necessity, with traffic congestion often causing lengthy commutes, especially during rush hour. In fact, walking is not a preferred mode of transportation in my city, despite the proximity of many attractions. The result is some of the worst traffic in the world, coupled with scarce parking options. Interestingly, the city has seen a significant amount of construction in recent years, with new apartment buildings sprouting up left and right. While this has made my city a popular destination, many residents are concerned about the influx of new residents and the strain it will put on the roads. Housing options in my neighborhood are equally diverse, with a mix of single-family homes, duplexes, and smaller apartment buildings. While I've lived here for a while, I must admit that I'm not familiar with most of my neighbors, and the community has become less tight-knit over the years. However, I do have fond memories of my childhood, playing outside with my next-door neighbor and a few other friends from the neighborhood who were around the same age.

My neighborhood is a unique and nostalgic place, a blend of old and new. Many of the houses are single-family homes, but some have been converted into duplexes, still connected but with a distinct sense of individuality. My home, like the ones surrounding it, exudes a sense of familiarity, reminiscent of a bygone era when suburban living was the epitome of the American dream. This dream, once a beacon of hope and security, now seems to be slipping away, yet my neighborhood and others like it continue to hold onto it, a reminder that it's still within reach. The residents, though less optimistic than they once were, still cling to the idea, evident in the care taken to maintain their small front yards and the presence of a car or two in every driveway. The sound of children playing, oblivious to the world beyond their neighborhood, is a constant reminder of the joy and innocence of youth. The local public school, a 90-year-old institution, remains a source of inspiration for the young and nostalgia for the older residents. The churches, though few and often empty, still serve as a gathering place for the community, while the basketball courts, always bustling with activity, seem to be a symbol of the neighborhood's resilience. Despite the differences in architecture, the houses feel strangely familiar, a testament to the enduring spirit of this community. A large supermarket, "Super A," is owned by a Yemeni family, one of the few Arab families in the neighborhood, which is predominantly African American. The streets are wide and well-maintained, and the kids often play football, pausing only to allow cars to pass. Many residents have lived in the neighborhood for generations, sharing stories of a time when everyone knew each other. The neighborhood has evolved over the years, with a karate school giving way to a pharmacy, and a small movie theater showing classic films at a discounted price, a haven for the elderly who appreciate its nostalgic charm. A single expressway passes through the adjacent town, but the entrance and exit are located just outside our town. A petition was once launched to build an exit within our town, but the elderly residents, fearing it would ruin the neighborhood's character, convinced the city council to reject the proposal. We're currently debating the mascot for our new high school, and I think a cyborg with a country accent and a log cabin would be a fitting representation of our town's unique character.

At first glance, the area in question appears to be a typical residential neighborhood behind a shopping strip, a place that might not seem like a desirable place to live. However, hidden behind the old, abandoned Whole Foods and the seasonal hotels lies a thriving community. These neighborhoods are tucked away and often overlooked, but they house a series of apartment complexes situated alongside each other like intricately arranged Russian nesting dolls. While one complex has been the subject of unsavory headlines, the surrounding apartments offer a glimpse into a different world, one that remains largely unknown to the local residents.

Across the street, a satellite campus of a community college stands as a quiet, sleepy presence, its students filtering in one by one to begin their day with a cup of coffee in hand. Commuters driving by often get delayed by the campus traffic, but those who live in the area take it in stride. Nearby, a rehabilitation center provides care for those recovering from unfortunate injuries, its cheerful porch furniture and lazily rotating ceiling fan creating a warm and inviting atmosphere. Just a short walk away, a park bustles with children playing, their laughter carrying through the air as they run and play among the flowers and greenery. Seniors walk their dogs on the walking path, exchanging stern looks with the teenagers on skateboards, while the teenage girls gossip and giggle by the playground equipment.

A strip mall nearby houses a variety of local businesses, including a sushi restaurant offering affordable food, a swimming supply store, and a nail salon. You can even get your pool filled for the season while getting a manicure and enjoying hibachi chicken all at once - a quintessential strip mall experience. A frozen yogurt shop, where customers can create their own treats with a variety of toppings, is also part of the mix, often frequented by teenagers who stop by after a skate session or a vape break. This neighborhood is a slice of Americana, a piece of history that remains unchanged and timeless, even in the sleepy south.

As we drove down a two-lane country road lined with endless cornfields, she asked, "Where is everything?" I smiled knowingly, aware that she was taken aback by the vast open spaces. Growing up in a town where the local grocery store was just a five-minute walk from her front door, she was unused to such a desolate landscape. I shared stories of my own rural Ohio upbringing, and in that moment, she finally grasped where I came from.

The road led us past a quarry, its waters reflecting the sky, and then to a small development where I lived. The houses, primarily made of brick and stucco, were surrounded by half-acre plots of land, meticulously maintained by their owners. In the spring, vibrant flowers bloomed alongside the changing Midwestern trees, while driveways were lined with gleaming Mercedes-Benz luxury cars, polished to perfection after a good old-fashioned wash.

As we continued down the road, I pointed out my grey stucco home, where my friendly Korean neighbor often spent his days mowing his lawn, his John Deere Zero Turn mower humming in the background. His warm demeanor and genuine nature made him a beloved figure in the neighborhood, and locals couldn't help but chuckle at his antics. Though his wit had mellowed with age, his past as a doctor remained a testament to his remarkable life story. He often blended into the surroundings, becoming one with the grass and his trusty mower.

Beyond my home, a small stream flowed into the quarry, accompanied by the soothing sounds of bullfrogs, the gentle current, and the occasional "moo" from nearby farms. Across a handmade wooden bridge lay an untouched oasis, teeming with naturally growing trees, herbs, and wildflowers. This was the setting where I spent countless hours of my childhood, building tree forts, "hunting" (essentially chasing) animals, and forging friendships with my neighbors. Our winters were harsh, but there was beauty in the stark landscape. The once-lush trees became skeletal, their branches etched against the sky, and the yard transformed into an empty wilderness. The occasional snowfall brought a magical transformation, creating a winter wonderland overnight. My sister and I would spend hours building snowmen, making snow angels, and engaging in friendly snowball fights, our winter wonderland a place where nothing else mattered.

The first thing you need to grasp about Portland, Oregon is its definition of "weird." Unofficially, the term is reflected in a building that serves multiple purposes - a pizza joint, bar, music venue, and strip club - with the slogan "Keep Portland Weird" emblazoned on its exterior. For some, this phrase is a nostalgic reminder of the city's past, a time when it was less well-known and less expensive, fostering unique and creative subcultures. Others see it as an invitation to visit a place where people still proudly identify as "weird" - a compliment this time around. Despite the influx of affluent Californians and the constant construction of condos to accommodate them, Portland's essence remains. "Weird" doesn't imply a complete rejection of the norm, but rather an acceptance of things that are often shunned. Like the rest of the country, we purchase many of our goods from China. There are numerous ways to be "weird," but Portland also has its fair share of normalcy. The city boasts yoga studios, hipsters, and business professionals, showcasing that there's a spectrum of weirdness. Perhaps the defining characteristic of Portland is its tendency to take life less seriously. In my neighborhood, as in many others, you'll find colorful homes, gardens bursting with flowers, herbs, and vegetables, and the occasional free box in the summer. Free boxes are essentially containers filled with items people are giving away, and they can be a treasure trove of unexpected delights. They often contain clothes and books, but you might stumble upon anything. The thrill of discovering a hidden gem while walking through a Southeast Portland neighborhood is what Portland is all about - at least, that's what it means to me, but I'm just one of the many weird and wonderful people who call this city home. Some of my neighbors would never dream of rummaging through a box on the sidewalk. They'd opt for goat yoga or Timbers matches instead. Portland is a melting pot of people who adore diverse activities and pursuits. We're a city filled with dreamers, some of whom spend too much time at the bar pondering their aspirations. Yes, Portland struggles with a drug issue, which often stems from deeper mental health problems. The constant rain and dreary skies throughout the year may also contribute to this issue. Furthermore, we have a homelessness problem, which seems to be a universal challenge in the United States. While Portland's social services are more comprehensive than in many other cities, they still fall short. The non-homeless population vacillates between empathy and disdain, a sentiment that's all too common in many areas of the country.

In the north, the mountains remain steadfast, watching as the sun rises and sets with each passing day. They are a constant presence in my life, a reminder of the beauty and power of nature. No matter how consumed I become by work and daily life, the mountains remain unchanging, unshakeable, and unmoved by life's turmoil. On the most stressful and overwhelming days, they call out to me, and when I turn to them, they offer a sense of peace and solace, granting me the strength to carry on, one day at a time.

It was during my undergraduate studies that I first fell under the spell of these mountains. The university itself has its own share of breathtaking landscapes, from its buildings to its ponds and trees, which have a special place in my heart. However, it is the mountains that hold a special significance for me. As I walk through the town, I'm surrounded by a unique blend of old and new. The town's downtown area is a charming mix of faded brick buildings, lined with restaurants and offices, which gives off an aura of antiquity. Yet, this tranquil atmosphere doesn't last for long, as I can easily escape the bustle and head back to the serene small-town charm.

This dichotomy of atmospheres, existing in such close proximity, creates a captivating vibe that invites exploration. As I wander through the town, I've created many cherished memories, each tied to a specific location. Whether it's strolling past the rusty swings in the park after a late-night study session or racing through the downtown area to catch a movie at the fancy theater, courtesy of the university's tickets. On the other hand, the town has also witnessed its share of difficult moments, as life often does. The ponds, in particular, have become a place for reflection and introspection, especially during the late hours of the night. As I watch the turtles, ducks, and insects live their lives, each with their own purpose, I'm left to ponder my own sense of purpose and meaning in life.

One morning, as I walked past the pond and the park, the sun broke through the palm trees, casting a warm glow across the sky. As I gazed up at the sunrise, I found myself walking north, drawn to the mountains that stood tall and proud in the distance. They had been there all along, a constant presence in my life, and as I looked at them, they seemed to stir within me a sense of determination and perseverance.

Visiting Bensonhurst, Brooklyn, will be an uncomplicated task due to its excellent public transportation system, which is one of the most popular modes of transportation in New York City. As you explore the area, you'll notice the urban atmosphere of Bensonhurst, making you feel like you're still in New York City. The neighborhood has undergone significant changes over the past two decades, with a considerable influx of Asian residents. As a result, you'll find Asian-owned stores on almost every block while walking through the area, with supermarkets and laundromats being the most popular options. These businesses are in high demand among locals, offering high-quality food at affordable prices and great convenience. Just a short walk from where I live, there are four Asian supermarkets within a two-minute walking distance from each other, making it incredibly easy to access grocery stores. Despite the Asian influence, Bensonhurst is a diverse neighborhood with a mix of immigrants, their children, and long-time residents. Many of the prominent businesses in the area are owned by Asian individuals, but you'll also find other types of stores and services. Additionally, a nearby park has been renovated and features a variety of amenities, including ten basketball courts, a soccer or baseball field, four handball courts, a playground for kids, and a water fountain for kids to enjoy during the summer months. Given the location in New York City, the park is a melting pot of different cultures, and you'll see people from various backgrounds coexisting and having a great time. Unlike other areas, Bensonhurst is dominated by co-op living buildings and condominium apartments, with most residents living in two-family houses. While the people are generally friendly, there is a downside to living here – the noise level is high. Every day, you'll hear cars blasting music as they drive by, or people speeding by, which can be disturbing. If you plan to visit at night, be aware of your surroundings as the neighborhood can be a bit rough, with some individuals prone to starting trouble. I've personally had some negative experiences in the past, including physical altercations, but these incidents occurred many years ago. More recently, there have been cases of package theft, which is a common issue in the area. Lastly, a pet peeve of mine is the lack of cleanliness in the neighborhood, particularly when it comes to dog waste. Every morning, you'll likely see dog waste along your walk to the train station or supermarket. To avoid any discomfort, be mindful of your surroundings and keep your shoes clean when walking through Bensonhurst.

The neighborhood I live in lacks sidewalks, and it seems everything slopes downward. My house is situated at the crest of the steepest hill in the area, earning it a nickname among locals as the 'workout hill.' Joggers frequently use this route as part of their daily routine. Because there are no sidewalks on my street, pedestrians are forced to share the road, which has several potholes and can be hazardous to navigate. The telephone and electric wires strung up around the block appear tattered and worn due to frequent branch and debris damage from storms, requiring constant repairs. The area experiences a lot of rain and storms, resulting in numerous evergreen trees surrounding the neighborhood. However, the residents despise these trees, as they obstruct the view of the ocean. As a result, houses are built high up on the hill, with large glass-fronted second stories that offer panoramic views of the bay. The sight is stunning at sunset when the water is illuminated from below and the sky turns orange. Unfortunately, the weather is often cloudy, and the sunlight is usually filtered through a haze. Most days are overcast and damp, with moss growing on any surface it can, including roofs, cars, and railings. I once left my car parked in my driveway for a month, and when I returned, it was covered in moss and needed three hours to clean off. The neighborhood is relatively quiet, with a nearby school being the only place with a lot of children. The majority of residents are older, many of whom are retired. Dogs are a common sight in the area, often seen lounging in front yards or racing down the street. If you leave a door or window open, there's a high chance of them sneaking into your house. I've personally encountered a stray dog that wandered into my living room and had to coax it back out the front door. The area is also home to wild rabbits, some of which are quite large. Gardeners dislike them because they dig up plant roots and burrow into lawns. However, my cats enjoy hunting them, and they've managed to eliminate most of the rabbits from the neighborhood. The usual assortment of birds can be seen in the area, including small sparrows, hummingbirds, and the occasional hawk or eagle that swoops by until the neighborhood crows chase it away. There are no stores nearby, but hiking downhill to the waterfront reveals a few restaurants serving fresh seafood. Although there isn't a wide beach, the rocks along the shore offer a fun spot to skip stones into the water. The bay itself is relatively narrow, and on most days, the opposite shoreline can be seen through the mist.

My home is situated in a typical suburban neighborhood in a small town in Tennessee. It's a quiet community, located at the intersection of two state highways, which brings a moderate amount of traffic through the area. However, this hasn't significantly impacted the peaceful atmosphere of the neighborhood. With minimal turnover in residents, I've become familiar with most of the faces in the community. People spend their days tending to their lawns and daily chores, giving the area a serene and laid-back feel. During the winter, the kids in the neighborhood take advantage of a nearby hill, using it as a makeshift sledding spot. As we live at the front corner of our street, we get to see everyone passing by, making us well-acquainted with the cars they drive. We always take note when we spot an unfamiliar vehicle. Many of our neighbors enjoy taking walks, either for exercise or to stroll their dogs. Children can be seen riding their bikes, and the sounds of laughter and playfulness fill the air. Since we work from home, we spend a lot of time indoors. Our household consists of four members – my wife and I, along with our two daughters, aged eleven and fourteen. This familiarity has led to a sense of normalcy, with our presence being a familiar sight in the neighborhood. When we do venture outside, we enjoy the fresh air, even on rainy days. Occasionally, we fire up the grill on our back patio, and the savory aroma of barbecue wafts through the air. The smell of freshly cut grass is a common occurrence from March to October, as our neighborhood is filled with trees, providing ample shade and an abundance of leaves during the fall. This, in turn, leads to the annual task of raking and burning leaves. I find the smell of burning leaves invigorating, signaling the arrival of fall. Lately, our area has experienced mild winters, making the season feel like an extended fall. Our garage is located at the back of the house, so we rarely use the front door, except when someone knocks. I often work on projects in the garage, and when the doors are open, I feel more connected to the community. During holidays like Thanksgiving and Christmas, the neighborhood is relatively quiet, with the occasional influx of visiting relatives and out-of-town guests. Overall, I'm content with our decision to live here. If it weren't for the through street, it would be an ideal community.

Living in my neighborhood is like being in the heart of the desert, where the horizon stretches as far as the eye can see and the landscape is predominantly brown. Unless you've experienced life in this arid environment firsthand, it can be challenging to grasp the feeling of seeing endless expanses of dirt and the occasional well-manicured lawn that stands out like a gem. When I first moved here in the 1990s, the neighborhood was relatively secluded, with houses scattered far apart. However, over the years, the area has undergone significant changes, with new developments sprouting up and the once-quaint atmosphere gradually giving way to a more urban feel. This trend is not unique to my neighborhood, as many areas are undergoing similar transformations. While the community is generally friendly, like any urban area, it has its share of good and bad. My neighborhood is actually one of the nicer areas, with a mix of long-time residents who are warm and welcoming. The local stores are largely chain establishments, such as discount grocery stores and big-box retailers. If you're looking for specialty stores or upscale shopping options, you may need to venture elsewhere. The job market in my city seems to be dominated by the construction industry, likely due to the area's ongoing development and the abundance of open spaces available for building. As someone who works in construction as a drywall and T-bar installer, I'm both fascinated and a bit apprehensive about the rapid growth. After leaving a major city, I'm not eager to see my hometown become too urbanized. Nevertheless, the high desert landscape has its unique charm, and the diverse wildlife is a major draw for many visitors. The region's harsh climate and geography have created intricate ecosystems that require protection and care. As residents, it's essential to learn about the wildlife and take steps to coexist peacefully. My family and I have adapted well to the desert environment, and my children are particularly enthusiastic about spotting lizards and insects. In fact, as I write this, they're outside attempting to catch various specimens. While there are few attractions in the immediate area, Victorville offers a unique experience for families. If you plan a visit, consider timing it with the annual San Bernardino County Fair, which provides an excellent blend of entertainment and local culture. For a more refreshing experience, head to Wrightwood to enjoy the snow-covered mountains and take up winter sports. If you're interested in the natural history and cultural heritage of the high desert, the Victor Valley Museum is an excellent destination, featuring a range of exhibits on geology, paleontology, Native American artifacts, and historical objects that showcase the development of the area.

When asked to describe my living environment, I tend to view it from a unique perspective. Unlike others who call a traditional neighborhood home, my situation is somewhat distinct. I consider the college campus where I reside to be my neighborhood, and the people in my dormitory to be my community. I also extend this definition to include the surrounding campus, albeit to a lesser extent. Despite this peculiarity, my campus shares some common characteristics with more conventional neighborhoods. Like any traditional neighborhood, my college environment has a mix of residential spaces, people from diverse backgrounds, stores, and recreational areas.

Let's start by examining the types of residential spaces that make up my neighborhood. To clarify, I'll break down the three primary types of housing found in my area: apartments, houses, and dormitories. In the apartments, 2-4 people typically share a room, with 4-6 rooms on each floor. These multi-story buildings usually accommodate around 20 individuals. In contrast, the houses available for rent are typically 2-4 bedroom setups, often occupied by alumni. However, these are less common, with only a few scattered throughout the neighborhood. Lastly, the dormitories house hundreds of students, with rooms usually shared by two people, with some exceptions.

Moving on to the people, my school prides itself on its diversity, which is reflected in the makeup of my neighborhood. There's a mix of people from different cultures and age groups living in my neighborhood. Staff members often reside in the houses within the neighborhood, while newer students opt for dormitory-style housing and older students choose apartment-style living. Due to the diverse nature of my neighborhood, it's challenging to capture its essence through words alone, so I'll move on to the stores and parks.

Given that my school is a self-sufficient community, it boasts a variety of stores and a single park within its boundaries. The stores offer a range of dining options, as well as the university's unique brands of clothing and grocery stores. This self-sufficiency means that most necessities can be found within the neighborhood's limits. The park serves as a playground for the diverse residents, maintained and enjoyed by everyone in the community, free from crime and kept clean for the benefit of all.

After living in my current neighborhood for about a decade, I've gained a deeper understanding of its unique character. When I first moved here from Riverdale to Stockbridge, I was initially sad, missing the life I had left behind. Admittingly, I even cried because I loved my old neighborhood and friends, but my parents made the decision to relocate to a better neighborhood with improved housing and schools. Over time, I adapted to my new surroundings and formed new friendships, as well as had some disagreements with classmates. I've had limited interactions with my neighbors throughout the years, but Mr. Glen and his children, along with Dennis, who lived next door to us, have been kind and like a family to me. I cherish the memories we've shared, such as attending Mr. Glen's remarriage, which was an enjoyable experience. I also recall the time I caught the white strap from Ms. Veda's leg when she threw it, although I unfortunately missed the flowers. We danced the night away, and I particularly enjoyed spending time with Marsharii, one of Mr. Glen's daughters. Although I haven't seen her since, I hope she's thriving. The neighborhood can be confusing to navigate, but with the aid of a GPS, I've been able to explore it more. I've spent time with friends like Kason and Curtis, and we'd often play video games and enjoy life to the fullest. I'd also visit the park to appreciate nature, which brings me a sense of calmness and peace. I'd bring sticks from Home Depot to practice my balance and, if I can, my bokken wooden sword. It's been nice to have a basketball and tennis court nearby, even though I haven't played in a while. My dad and I were introduced to tennis by Mr. Graves, and we'd have a great time, even though he pushed us hard. I'm grateful for the many fond memories I've made in this neighborhood, and I believe the best is yet to come.

Living in my neighborhood, which is conveniently located close to the college I attend, has its advantages. The area is filled with apartment buildings, and while they may not be the most modern, they are affordable and offer a range of amenities within walking distance. Several restaurants and bars in the area are reasonably priced and provide a fun atmosphere. One of these bars has recently changed its name, and although it's become pricier, it still maintains decent service and quality drinks. The locals are generally friendly, comprising mostly college students and low-income residents who can afford the affordable housing. The presence of an elementary school nearby means there are plenty of children in the area, adding to the neighborhood's lively atmosphere.

However, I'm not particularly interested in getting to know my neighbors, as they seem to have a habit of smoking marijuana. In an attempt to address this issue, the management of my building installed an air freshener unit near their door, which my boyfriend and I found amusingly ironic. The surrounding buildings are mostly old but have been renovated from the inside. A short walk away, there's a brand-new apartment complex, but I'm not a fan of it due to concerns about its construction quality. The rent is steep, making it seem like a bad investment, but the location near the university makes it a popular choice.

There's a budget-friendly eatery near my place that serves food on paper plates and relies heavily on microwave-cooked meals. Across from this restaurant is a gas station, which has a reputation for being a difficult workplace. Thanks to a recent city-funded renovation, the road has been repaved, and a pleasant sidewalk, lush grass, and greenery have improved the area's appearance. Despite this, the apartment complex where I reside is surrounded by a dense canopy of trees. While some of the trees were recently cut down, leaving stumps behind, my area still boasts a higher number of trees compared to the neighboring streets.

The area behind my apartment complex features a tree line, followed by another set of apartments. 43rd Street, which runs parallel to 42nd Street where I live, has a more run-down appearance, with crumbling sidewalks and dilapidated buildings. The presence of trees on this street may be an attempt to conceal its less-than-desirable state. Notably, the majority of the crime in my area has been reported at an apartment complex on 43rd Street, although it's worth noting that I don't blame them entirely, given the transient population and similar issues at other apartment complexes across the street from me.

Despite its flaws, I'm generally content with my living situation. The affordability, proximity to the university, and accessibility to shopping and public transportation – including two bus stops – make it an ideal location for me.

My neighborhood is a charming collection of duplexes nestled on a cul-de-sac, each one painted in a cheerful yellow color with white porches and green metal roofs. The homes are strategically placed to create the illusion of individual dwellings, and while they may look alike from the outside, they all have their own unique character inside. The residents are a friendly bunch, with most of us knowing each other well, and we often gather at the end of the driveway in the evenings to chat while the children play outside. It's a refreshing respite from the hustle and bustle of modern life, reminiscent of a simpler time. We're surrounded by lush fields, towering trees, and a brilliant blue sky dotted with puffy white clouds. However, this season has brought its challenges, including tornado warnings and a recent close call that prompted us to seek shelter. I was among those huddled in the bathtub with my little dog and a few essentials, while my big dog remained in the living room, anxious and barking in protest. The storm brought large hail that pounded the ground, and as the temperature dropped dramatically, the road became a steaming expanse. The hail melted instantly as it hit the hot pavement, and as the skies cleared, a beautiful double rainbow appeared. I quickly grabbed my camera to capture the moment, and the resulting photos were met with amazement from my friends and family on social media. The neighborhood remained quiet for a while, but as the storm passed, life returned to normal, with mothers and children resuming their evening routines. I'm grateful to have found this welcoming community in my new home, especially after moving from New Hampshire to North Carolina. I'm captivated by the Southern drawl that fills the air, and I appreciate the unique charm of our neighborhood, where each apartment may look the same from the outside, but has its own distinct character within. I enjoy taking leisurely walks through the large field behind my home, strolling down to the picturesque pond that's perfect for contemplation. The sounds of deer, bullfrogs, and roosters fill the air, creating a serene atmosphere that makes me feel like I'm living in a small village. Even the nearby farm's donkey joins in with its evening bray, letting us know it's there. I feel fortunate to have discovered this hidden gem of a neighborhood, located just a short 40-minute drive from the vibrant city of Charlotte.

A little over a decade ago, I found myself moving into a new neighborhood as I was about to enter the eighth grade. Initially, making friends was a challenge, but I eventually formed close bonds with a neighbor who lived just two houses down and another resident from my own street. Though they no longer reside in the area, the memories we shared remain vivid. One thing that has remained constant is that the people who were here when I first arrived are largely still here today. My neighborhood shares many characteristics with the typical American suburban community, featuring a mix of two-story houses. Weekends and warm weather typically bring the sounds of children playing outside, and the neighborhood is generally quiet during the weekdays. Over the years, I've never had any issues with my neighbors, and it's clear that they value respecting one another's personal space. The neighborhood's safety has earned my trust, as I've had no problems with packages being stolen from my porch, even after ordering several online. I've come to feel a sense of security in knowing that my neighbors have my back. A nearby park, just a short walk from my home, holds a special place in my heart. I spent countless hours playing games like basketball, football, and baseball with the other kids in the neighborhood. Although I also had a memorable - albeit unpleasant - experience of getting elbowed in the nose during a game, the positive memories far outweigh the negative ones. Nowadays, I often visit the park with my younger cousin's children, who still enjoy playing on the swings and slides. The mere thought of going to the park brings back a flood of nostalgic feelings for me. One thing that makes my neighborhood stand out is its diversity. Within a one-mile radius, you can find a variety of restaurants serving Chinese, Indian, Mexican, and Italian cuisine. However, with the rise of food delivery apps like GrubHub and DoorDash, many people now opt for having their food delivered rather than venturing out. Fast food establishments are also prevalent, but you can find those in many suburban neighborhoods. The neighborhood is well-equipped with stores that cater to all your needs, including multiple dry cleaners, a Walgreens, a CVS, and a Jewel-Osco grocery store - a popular chain in the Midwest. There's even an Indian-owned store if you're in the mood for homemade or pre-made Indian dishes. Overall, I'm grateful for my neighborhood, and comparing it to the stories I see on social media and in the news makes me appreciate the harmony we enjoy here.

The small town of Johnston, situated in South Carolina, is a quaint community that flies under the radar. While it doesn't stand out from other towns in the region, it plays a significant role in the local agriculture sector. The town proudly claims the title of Peach Capital of the World, as evident from the welcoming sign. The landscape is primarily dominated by farmland, with vast expanses of peach trees and cattle grazing areas. Houses outside the main town area are spaced far apart, often two-story structures with metal roofs or gray shingles to mitigate the scorching summer heat. These homes are frequently situated away from the main road, with the front fields used for livestock or crops. The main town area is marked by a single traffic light at a four-way stop, where the town's few stores are located. Residents can choose from a limited selection of eateries, including Hong Kong, a family-run Chinese restaurant, Fiesta Mexican Restaurant, or Gary's, a local burger chain. A pizzeria once existed but has since closed down. Maxwell and Halford Drug, a small, family-owned pharmacy, is notable for its Cherry Coca-Cola sales. A small, upscale grocery store called Independent Grocers Alliance (or IGA) is the town's sole grocery store, although many residents prefer to shop at a nearby Walmart in Batesburg-Leesville for their main grocery needs. Dollar General is the most popular store in town, offering a wide range of everyday items and attracting a steady crowd from opening to closing time. Possibilities Furniture & More, a quaint furniture store run by a well-respected local woman, has been a staple in the community for years, even employing two movers to deliver purchased furniture. The store shares a building with Clark's Cuts and Kennels, a small pet groomer offering various services. The town's medical and veterinary practices are located outside the main town area, with both being small but well-equipped to cater to the residents' needs. Johnston Elementary School is the town's only school, with students attending middle and high school in the adjacent town after completing fifth grade. Although the town lacks amenities like movie theaters, bowling alleys, or parks, it has initiated plans to develop a 2.5-acre recreational area to attract visitors and provide families with more activities. Despite its limitations, Johnston remains a charming town that could easily go unnoticed by passing drivers.

The first time I heard about my neighborhood was in a podcast about people who went missing. It was a surprising revelation, considering nearly every apartment in the area was renting for over a thousand dollars a month. I had never heard anything about that story, nor had any of my friends. It's possible that's because of the financial struggles many of us face. Some of my acquaintances have confided in me about the difficulties they experience at night, unable to shake the feeling of uncertainty that comes with living paycheck to paycheck. Despite the high costs, we've learned to adapt and live frugally over time. You develop an appreciation for the smell of flea market finds and the musty aroma of second-hand items. As we age, we often begin to notice that we smell less. Some turn to smoking, while others become desensitized to the state of their surroundings. However, the allure of the flea market persists, with its eclectic mix of items and nostalgic charm. Here, there are three thrift stores within walking distance, each offering a unique shopping experience. If you start on the far side, you can visit two charity thrift stores, a library, a rare book shop, and a curio store. Downtown is bustling, with cars and people filling the streets every morning, but the thrift stores remain eerily quiet. Despite the constant flow of people and vehicles outside, the stores themselves are silent oases where you can lose yourself for hours. Every year, the city seems to grow more crowded, with cars and people flooding the streets. This has led to growing pains, as the city struggles to balance its rapid expansion with the needs of its residents. It reminds me of New York City, where everyone is focused on their own goals and aspirations, and nobody seems to ask much of you. You can maintain a sense of independence and solitude, and people will generally leave you alone. This is a stark contrast to the South, where being concerned for someone's well-being is seen as a sign of care. In this city, people tend to respect your boundaries and let you keep to yourself. It's a lively place to live, with the sounds of a pianist next door and amateur vocalists upstairs providing a constant background hum. In many ways, our apartment building feels more like a community of friends than a collection of strangers. We come together for special occasions, celebrate birthdays, mourn losses, and support one another when needed. I feel fortunate to live here, surrounded by people I've grown to appreciate and respect. We take care of our shared space, exchange favors, and enjoy each other's company. It's a pleasant arrangement, and I'm grateful for the positive relationships I've formed with my neighbors. Despite living in a massive, soulless modernist development, it's the kindness and camaraderie of my community that makes me feel like I haven't completely sacrificed my humanity.

The area where I reside is a quintessential example of a cookie-cutter suburban community. The presence of a homeowner's association is unmistakable in my neighborhood, where every detail seems to be meticulously managed. As you drive through the neighborhood, you'll notice a sea of well-maintained single-family homes, all thanks to the HOA's efforts. The front yards are remarkably uniform, featuring a small patch of grass, decorative pebbles, and short driveways. Every so often, you'll catch a glimpse of a small tree or two. The proliferation of two-car garages is another striking feature of the neighborhood. As you continue driving, you'll notice newly paved concrete roads, devoid of potholes, and maintained to perfection. The architecture is a mix of one-story and two-story homes, with no two houses looking exactly alike. One distinctive aspect of the neighborhood is the mail distribution system, where residents share a large grouping of mailboxes at the end of the street, accessed using a key. This emphasis on uniformity is a hallmark of the HOA's attention to detail.

Located on the outskirts of the nearby city, my neighborhood straddles the line between rural and suburban living. As a result, we enjoy an abundance of open space, perfect for various community amenities. There are multiple pools, which are well-maintained and gated, as well as walking trails where residents can stroll or walk their dogs. The neighborhood's size allows for a leisurely jog or run, providing ample opportunities for exercise without needing to visit a park. The community is predominantly made up of retirees, creating a safe and caring environment where everyone looks out for one another. A smaller but significant population of middle-aged and young professionals adds a dynamic element to the neighborhood. The nearby city, while surprisingly large in terms of population, retains a small-town feel. We have a wide range of amenities, including a single mall that caters to our needs. While it may not be the largest mall, it's sufficient for our community. Getting to any significant destination takes around 15 minutes by car, after which we're greeted with a variety of stores, from upscale grocery stores to bargain outlets. Overall, my neighborhood is a safe, well-maintained, and typical example of suburban living, with its own unique charm and amenities.

I reside in a small Midwestern town situated just outside the suburban areas of a major city. My immediate neighborhood on the east side is the most economically disadvantaged area in the town, marked by low property values and a predominantly low-income demographic. However, this area is not uninviting or unpleasant, and it's characterized by friendly residents who greet each other with a smile and a wave when passing by. Although crime rates are slightly higher in this area compared to other parts of town, they remain generally low. Over the past decade, there have been a few violent incidents, including shootings and a homicide, within a few blocks of my home. A heartbreaking example of this is the loss of my next-door neighbors' son, who was tragically shot outside a local bar last year. Fortunately, my family has not directly experienced crime, except for the occasional loss of small items from our porch if we forget to bring them inside. The town where I live has been severely impacted by the opioid epidemic that has ravaged many parts of the United States. Sadly, numerous lives have been lost due to fentanyl overdoses. Fortunately, there are numerous resources available to combat this epidemic, including addiction rehabilitation centers and Narcan training sessions for families and friends of those affected by addiction. Despite these challenges, my town boasts many positive attributes. My son's elementary school is exceptional, with a dedicated staff from the principal to the teachers and support staff. Despite his special needs, he has not faced any bullying, thanks to the school's overwhelmingly positive atmosphere, which he thoroughly enjoys. Our active PTO organizes various events throughout the year to promote family engagement and educational progress. Due to the town's high poverty rate, the elementary school provides free breakfast and lunch to all students, ensuring that no child goes hungry. The school's inclusive environment treats every child and family with dignity, regardless of their financial situation, and costs for school fees, supplies, and field trips are reasonable. The City Council and staff have implemented several improvements to the town's appearance, including repaving roads, landscaping, and refurbishing city parks. However, most of these enhancements have taken place in the center of town and on the west side, where shopping areas and traffic are concentrated, leaving the east side, where I reside, relatively neglected, which is a source of contention for my neighborhood. Overall, I find living in this town to be enjoyable. The people are generally friendly, the schools are exceptional, there are sufficient shopping options to meet our needs, and our home, although not worth much, is comfortable and meets our basic requirements. We have lived in this town for over 16 years and cannot imagine calling any other place home.

My neighborhood is a vibrant tapestry of cultures, nestled on a hill surrounded by buildings steeped in history. I reside in a 7-story apartment building directly across from a historic theater and just a block away from a trendy arcade bar that attracts a diverse crowd on warm summer evenings. The bar's popularity can be gauged by the frequent lines of people waiting to get in, especially on weekends during June and July. A few blocks up lies the local city park, a significant green space in an otherwise urban setting. The park is encircled by concrete, with stairs embedded in the walls for easy access. During the harsh winter months, homeless individuals set up their tents in neat rows along the sidewalk and the expansive steps. Although snowfall is scarce, the torrential rains in mid-winter often make it challenging to stay warm. By clustering their tents together in the heart of town, they can share body heat and stay relatively warmer. Moreover, they are within walking distance to the nearest family center, where they can access essential amenities like bathing and showering facilities.

While my city boasts impressive historical architecture, what I cherish most about my neighborhood is the culture of its residents. The area's past as a hub of gang violence, particularly during the 1970s and 1980s, still lingers in local lore. Stories of federal authorities and the DEA's efforts to clean up the streets are passed down through generations, even among newcomers like myself. Despite its reputation as one of the city's rougher neighborhoods, the community continues to work towards maintaining a clean and safe environment. They take pride in their city and their block, showing that even in the face of adversity, they remain committed to their home.

The warning not to walk around the Hill after dark, especially for those who are white, is a poignant reminder of the neighborhood's complex history. As someone who can easily pass for a non-white individual, I sense a sense of belonging among the Hilltop residents. They recognize me as one of their own, someone who is acutely aware of the lingering social issues that plague our nation, including racism, cultural conditioning, and ignorance-fueled assumptions. The Hilltop is a place where I feel alive, where people have offered me kindness and support, from loaning me a jacket to helping me charge my phone on a rainy night. It's a community that values its residents, where I can find solace in the midst of grey, dreary days, and be reminded of my worth and beauty by strangers who take the time to look me in the eye and offer a gesture of kindness.

I reside in rural America, specifically a small town in Michigan. The landscape shifts from farmland to charming tourist destinations. There are no large city malls, no big-box stores like Walmart or Target, and no chain restaurants like Applebee's. If you need to go anywhere, you have to drive. Despite this, I live in one of the most breathtaking areas in the world, surrounded by water. My community is nestled between two beautiful lakes, Lake Michigan and Lake Charlevoix. Every corner of our town offers access to a beach where you can dip your toes in the water. The homes in my neighborhood are quintessential small-town America. They're not stacked on top of each other, and they're not cookie-cutter houses built to a uniform design. Instead, they're older homes, some updated and remodeled, others preserved in their original charm. Many of the houses have basements that are visible from the street, and you'll often see older aluminum siding on the houses. The neighborhood is a kaleidoscope of colors, with houses of every hue on the blocks surrounding my home. Most of the houses have yards with trampolines, playsets, and gardens, while some have fences to keep pets safe. The overall atmosphere is distinctly Midwestern, with hardworking families who strive to make a living and raise their children. On any given day, you'll see kids playing in the streets, neighbors walking their dogs, biking, or rollerblading. People in the community know each other, and it's not uncommon to see someone grilling in their yard and waving, or someone walking their dog from a few blocks away and smiling in greeting. The lawns are well-maintained, with green grass and neatly trimmed bushes. While it's not a neighborhood that immediately grabs your attention with its grandeur, it's a place where people feel safe and at peace. Within walking distance, you'll find the county sheriff's department and jail, the health department, the city recycling center, and baseball and softball fields where the sound of announcers calling out player names and scores fills the air. Our small-town airport is nearby, and you can hear the sounds of small planes taking off and landing even from inside your home. You can walk to get ice cream from the local shop, and if you're feeling adventurous, you can stroll downtown from our neighborhood. My kids can ride their bikes to the park, which is just eight blocks away. It's a wonderful place to call home.

original_texts:
Since I live in a large city, my neighborhood is extremely diverse. Residential areas are dispersed, seemingly randomly, between commercial areas, where a variety of businesses are run. Some of these businesses are made up of offices, while others are various stores, restaurants, and places of entertainment. There is no shortage of new restaurants to eat at, or stores to shop in. While some stores are large, well-known, brands that are owned by large corporations, small boutiques are also increasingly popular. They are not only located in various malls, but they also line the streets, which are often in walking distance of neighborhoods that would otherwise be quiet and serene, if not surrounded by so many points of interest. There are also a couple of nearby parks, and I have noticed that people frequent these parks with their young children. Speaking of the people, thereâ€™s actually quite a bit of diversity within my neighborhood. In one small location, we have a prominent LGBTQ+ community, an Orthodox Jewish community, and a collection of refugees and immigrants from the former Soviet Union. Spanning a little further outside of my neighborhood, there are many more individuals of various races and origins, although they are sometimes broken up into their own little communities within the city. We have locations known as Korea town, China town, Little Armenia, and many more, which are only a few miles away. However, only a few miles can prove to be a very lengthy drive. Driving a distance of only 10 miles can sometimes span two hours, due to traffic, especially during rush hour. Hardly anyone in my city walks anywhere, though. While certain locations of interest are inevitably close-by, the city is huge, and people do not generally prefer to commute on foot. As a result, we also have some of the worst traffic in the world, and it can be difficult to find parking spots just about anywhere. Ironically enough, there has been a great deal of construction in recent years, as large apartment buildings are being added to the city. It is seems to be a popular destination, but many residents are disappointed by the prospect of even more people moving in, and even more vehicles on the roads. There are many different types of houses in my city, however. Not everyone lives, or wishes to live, in a large apartment building. Residential areas are made up of houses, of various sizes, and smaller apartment buildings and condominiums. Some properties contain single-family homes, while others contain duplexes. This is true even within my immediately neighborhood, so there is also no lack of diversity in regards to housing options. Similarly, the neighborhood is made up of people of varying ages, and to be perfectly honest, I am not familiar with the majority of my neighbors. It is not really a tight-knit community these days, although I have many memories from my childhood of playing outside with my next-door neighbor, and a few other friends from the neighborhood, who were all close to my age.
My neighborhood is interesting. Most of the houses are single family, but there are a few homes that have been split into two, while still being attached, if that makes much sense. My home has a small yard in front of it and a small driveway to the left of the house. It, like most of the others, reminds you of a time not so long ago where living in the suburbs was the American dream. This dream at once seemed to embrace the people of this country, but now its pulling away. But my neighborhood and many more still remain, still call out to us and those who visit that the dream is still alive, and we are still holding onto it as best we can. The people don't feel as optomistic as they used to, the upkeep of the little yards are not what they used to be, but there is still a car or two in every driveway, still the youth play as if the world around them was the whole of their existence. The public school that has been here for almost 90 years still stands, still seems conjure a future in today's youth, while stirring up nostalgia in the older residents. The churches are few and far between, mostly empty, but the basketball courts are still full. All of the homes look different, but feel the same. There is a large supermarket called super "A" that has been owned by a large Yemni family, who are quite possible the only Arab family in the neighborhood. The vast majority of the residents are African American. The streets are wide and the kids usually play footbal, only stopping to allow the cars to pass. Most of the people in my neighborhood have been here for generations and most can tell stories of a past where everyone knew everyone. There was a karate school, but when hollywood stopped making karate kid movies, the kids stopped wanting to be the karate kid, so its now a pharmacy, because drugs make everything better, or so I've heard. There is also a small movie theatre that plays old movies at a discounted price, spared from the crowds by the youth's disdane for its lack of just release titles, but favored by the elders, who think it is a small price to pay for a night out, without the kids of course. There is a single expressway that passes through my town. Though the exit and entrance are in the town next to ours. There was once a petition to get and exit for our town. The youth supported it, while the elders refused. It seems that having the expressway in our town would ruin it, so said the elders who eventually persuaded the city council to deny the request. They are building a new highschool, and we are trying to decide on a mascott for our town. I think a cyborg with a country accent and a log cabin would be then best representation of my town.
You might pass it up on first glance - after all, it is a residential area behind a shopping strip, not a place one would assume there are places to live. At least, not places most people would want to live. But if you go behind the old, abandoned Whole Foods and walk back behind the hotels which are only occupied annually aside from a few stints in the summertime for family reunions, you'll find an entire bustling community. Within these communities, on these streets, are a handful of apartment complex - situated next to each other carefully like Russian nesting dolls that have been scrupulously, carefully taken apart and set beside each other in a line down the road, piecemeal. The first apartments you come upon are ones which have been on the news for some fairly unsavory dealings, so we won't focus on those too much - appearances, after all, can be deceiving. But the apartments beside that complex, and the two complexes beside that one, are a whole other world that almost no one living in this area knows about. Across from those complexes is a community college's satellite campus - a quiet, sleepy set of buildings standing sentinel beside the road, where students putter in with coffee in hand, yawning at 7 in the morning to begin their sleepy days. The iron gates creak open to admit them one by one, while commuters shake their fists out the window and groan at them for holding up traffic on days attendance is higher. The road t-bones into another residential road, with a park on one side and a rehabilitation center for people who have broken bones in unfortunate circumstances. The treatment center boasts cheerful porch furniture, and a lazily undulating ceiling fan which churns the warm, thick summertime air back and forth. Children run back and forth in the grass at the park across the street, cartwheeling and pinwheeling across the prickly green stalks while bees lazily turn in the flower patches by the road. Old retired folks walk their dogs on the walking path, scowling at the teenagers on their skateboards and nodding demurely at the teenage girls clustered by the playground equipment, gossiping about boys and the latest YouTube sensations. There is a sushi place in a strip mall beside the park that has inexpensive food but never seems too busy - a swimming supply store right beside that, and a nail salon nestled in between. You could fill your pool for the season while getting a manicure and eating hibachi chicken, all at once - the beauty of a strip mall. There is a frozen yogurt place there too, one of the DIY kind, and you often see the teens in the park clutching cold, sweating cups of frozen yogurt covered in toppings while they do stunts on their skateboards and vape because they believe it to be the coolest. The neighborhood in question is a slice of Americana - a piece of history in the sleepy south where hardly anything changes, not even time.
“Where is everything?” she asked as we drove past the corn fields which filled the horizon. “This is it!” I said, knowing she’d be in shock of the sparseness of the open landscape. She was from a town in which the grocery store was a 5 minute walk from her house--she’d never seen this much open space in her life. Taken back by the ubiquity of corn fields, I shared with her what it was like to grow up in rural Ohio, and in that moment, she finally knew who I was and where I came from. Driving down a two-lane country road, you will reach a quarry which is filled with water. Just past it is the small development I live in. The houses are mostly composed of brick and stucco. All the houses have at least a half an acre of land to themselves which everyone takes pride in maintaining. During springtime, annually planted flowers are abundant along with the midwestern trees that change with every season. The driveways are all filled with the highest end Mercedes Benz luxury cars that glisten in the midday sun after a good, old-fashioned car wash. Continuing along the road toward my grey stucco home, my Korean neighbor is always outside with a friendly face. He tends to spend the entire day mowing his lawn and can be heard singing over his mower’s hum. Everyone in the neighborhood gets a laugh out of him, but he is always genuine and an amazing person with a unique history. He has grown older and has lost some of his wit as he aged. In his past he was a doctor and usually blends in with the grass and his John Deer Zero Turn mower. Finally, you will reach my home. In the side yard, geese are abundant and are chased by our Terrier. Out back, there is a small stream that feeds into the quarry. Here, you can hear bullfrogs, the stream, and the occasional “moo” from the nearby farms. Across the handmade wooden bridge is an untouched oasis filled with naturally growing trees, herbs, and wildflowers. Here was where I spent most of my childhood. From building tree forts to ‘hunting’ animals (which mostly consisted of chasing them), there was always something to do and usually a neighborhood child available for friendship. The winters in my small town can be painfully brutal, yet there is nothing more beautiful. The yard transforms from a sea of green into an empty wilderness. The trees that once housed vibrant pink, purple, and orange flowers turn into barren skeletons of bark. When blessed with the occasional snowfall, a winter wonderland appears overnight. The backyard is lined with snow angels made by my little sister, and snowmen. My sister and I fought frequently as kids, and during the winter, snowballs were our weapon of choice. We’d build massive igloo-like forts to house our weapons, usually with branches, like an arsenal. In our own little wonderland was where we played pretend during a time where nothing else mattered. We were just young kids without a care in the world.
The first thing you have to understand about Portland, Oregon is the definition of "weird". The unofficial town slogan, on the back of a building that serves as a pizza joint, bar, music venue, strip club, and skirts the law on at least half of these endeavors, is "Keep Portland Weird". To some, this is a small cry to remember the Portland of the 90's and early 2000's, a Portland that was less known and less expensive, generating creative and unique subcultures. To others, it is a beckoning call - come to Portland, where people will still call you weird, but as a compliment this time. Despite the influx of affluent Californians and the constant construction of condominiums to house these Californians, Portland is still weird. Weird does not mean always accepting, but it does mean accepting of things that are normally not accepted. Weird does not mean we do not have modern conveniences and modern fights. Like the rest of the country, we buy most of our things from China. There are a million ways of being weird, of being not normal, but Portland has plenty of normal. Portland has yoga and hipsters and business professionals. Perhaps weird means we just take all of this less seriously. In my neighborhood, as in many Portland neighborhoods, we have colorful houses, home gardens with flowers and herbs and vegetables lining the streets, and free boxes in the summertime. Free boxes are traditionally cardboard boxes containing items someone is getting rid of, but they can be plastic bags or boxes. They contain something magical, a treasure just perfect for the person wandering by, a surprising amount of the time. Free boxes tend to have clothes and books, but they can have anything. The magical potential of walking through a Southeast Portland neighborhood is what Portland is all about. That is, what Portland is all about to me, but I am just one variety of weird among thousands. Some people I live among would never dream of picking their clothes out of a box on the sidewalk. Those people go to goat yoga (yes, yoga with real live goats) or Timbers matches (the city's soccer team). Portland is full of people who love all sorts of things. Portland is full of people who pursue our dreams, or dream about pursuing our dreams while spending too much time at the bar. Yes, Portland has a drug problem. Drug problems tend to be (at their root) mental health problems, and the constant rain through much of the year, plus the dreary clouds, appear to be a contributor. Portland has a homelessness problem too, which no one seems to know what to do with. The homeless population is drawn by the social services Portland offers, better than in most parts of the country, but our services are insufficient, as in all parts of the country. The non-homeless population wavers between care and hatred. In this, we are not weird at all.
The mountains are always there. In the north, bearing witness to the sun’s journey every dawn and every dusk. No matter how much I forget about them or how caught up with work and life I am to notice, they are there, unwavering, unopposed, and unphased by life’s tribulations. Then on days when I am the most stressed and wound, they demand to be seen, and when I turn to them they let me rest my anxious soul, lending me some strength to go on, one day at a time. I first moved here when I started my undergrad, and the mountains to the north of campus where what first captivated me.
